Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2010 02:20PM frosty1 wrote: A friend of mine had a niece that went through chemo and her onc center gave her a great cookbook.  He liked it so much he went out and bought one.  I just picked one up as well -- Betty Crocker Living with Cancer Cookbook.  It is written with the help of doctors and gives you ideas and recipes for dealing with sore mouth, nauseau, bone pain, what to eat when you don't want to eat.  Great resource.  I highly recommend it. And thank you so much for creating this thread.  Had my port put in on Thursday and start chemo on Wednesday.  I have my list of questions for my doc and my bag packed.  Thank you!

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2010 03:31PM - edited Jan 19, 2010 03:32PM by frosty1 When I was first diagnosed with DCIS in December, my first thought was "cut it off!"  As I had my 2nd biopsy and an U/S that showed 2 sites and one 6cm, the doctor recommended a mastectomy.  That was when I panicked and thought that no, really, a lumpectomy wouldn't be so bad.  That said, I am glad I had the mastectomy.  They found 2 spots of invasive cancer in my breast (thank goodness no node involvement).  My sister-in-law has gone 2 rounds with BC and had lumpectomies both times.  She said now that she wished she had just had the whole thing done and been over it.  It is a personal decision.  Some people are very attached to the girls and others aren't.  You need to make a decision you can be comfortable with for years to come --

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2010 08:16PM frosty1 wrote: Popping in from the January group to say YOU CAN DO THIS!  What I learned from my surgery:  the waiting and anticipation is WAY worse than the actual surgery.  You will want to get large button up shirts (hard to pull shirts over your head); ribbon works well to tie up your drains around your neck when you shower; get a wedge pillow to help you sleep sitting up or semi-reclined.  It is wonderful to have a group to go through this with ... they can answer questions about what is normal, prop you up when you are down, and help you laugh. Best wishes to all going through surgery this month.
